awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Sufficient Statistics for Multi-Agent Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses the science of Cyber-Physical Systems. In a multi-agent system, each agent is faced with the task of making decisions taking account of the objectives and actions of other agents, as well as the dynamics of the environment. In such a distributed system each agent receives measurements of its environment, and must infer both the state of the world as well as that of the other agents. The intellectual merits of this research are that it develops new efficient techniques for this information processing, which achieve run-time performance using algorithms that have low computational requirements. The project's broader significance and importance are that it will provide new mathematical and computational tools for use in many engineering applications, including the power grid, transportation networks, and other multi-agent systems, and will be transitioned to practice through professional activities such as workshops, development of educational material for graduates, undergraduates and teenagers, and outreach to industry.

The underlying mathematical and computation tools for this research are based on new methods for statistical filtering in a dynamic setting. One of the most important techniques for the design of software control systems constructs state estimates which are sufficient statistics for the associated decision problem.  However, conventional approaches to sufficient statistics and state estimation do not apply to the multi-agent setting. Recent results have given new sufficient statistics for this setting, and the research develops the theory and algorithms to allow these statistics to be used for multi-agent control of cyber-physical systems.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: One of the primary activities of this project is the development of the fundamental theory of sufficient statistics for decentralized control systems.  In order to obtain meaningful results, a formulation using convex geometry and control theory is necessary. At the highest level, we would like to be able to formulate decision problems in an abstract way which captures the key elements of formulations from several fields, including the theory of teams and the field of control systems, where one studies decentralized control, and the field of robotics, where one studies cooperative behavior and Markov decision processes.  In our work we have produced a framework which is sufficiently general to captures all of these formulations, and yet allows specialization and application to give new concrete methods and algorithms. We defined a new class of team sufficient statistics that we called weak team sufficient statistics.  We showed that this new class of statistics is not only sufficient for making optimal decisions, but also necessary. We have developed methods for leveraging low-dimensional representations in human-robot team settings. This low dimensional representation acts as a sufficient statistic and enables seamless communication between the human and robot.

Broader Impact: The principal investigators have mentored student robotics projects, with efforts to address inclusivity and diversity. They have also worked to mentor high-school student robotics teams as part of university programs. Technical and scientific outreach has been fostered by efforts to lead symposia and workshops.
